author: Tommy Werner
title: Portugal's Prego Roll: A Recipe
text:
A sandwich for dinner is sad; a steak sandwich for dinner is pure class.
But firing up a grill on Tuesday? It ain’t happening. A good Philly cheesesteak isn't exactly after-work friendly, either.
Related How I Learned to Cook the Most Expensive Steak Ever. Without Having a Heart Attack. View article No, a weeknight steak sandwich needs to stay simple and happen in one pan.
Enter the prego roll : strips of seared steak served on a pillowy roll that's been slathered with garlic butter and might be the simplest steak sandwich in the world.
Portuguese in origin, the prego roll is also eaten in Mozambique (a former Portuguese colony), neighboring South Africa, and as of late, at NYC restaurant Jack’s Wife Freda . Dean Jankelowitz, who owns the restaurant with his wife Maya, grew up in South Africa, where Portuguese chain restaurants like Nando’s served the piri-piri chicken and prego rolls that fueled some of his most important childhood food memories.
Now, at Jack's Wife Freda, Dean gets to serve some of that food. And thanks to Dean and Maya's new cookbook , we now can get our hands on some of their most-loved recipes—the prego roll among them.
To make the sandwich, skirt steak is marinated in garlic, soy sauce, and olive oil for an hour or up to overnight. Then it's quickly seared and piled onto that garlic butter-schmeared bun.
The bun is key. If you live close to a Portuguese bakery, go there and grab a few pillowy rolls. If that's not an option, any other soft roll will do—just make sure it's got a crisp enough outer crust to hold in all those steak juices.
When I talked to Dean on the phone, he admitted that he and Maya like to add a simple sauce—a blend of jalapeño and serrano peppers, cilantro, garlic, and olive oil, not unlike a salsa verde —to the sandwich. He also mentioned adding friseé or arugula, or perhaps avocado at the most. But he warned me not to get too crazy.
“Keeping it simple is the idea behind it,” he said. “You look at it, and it doesn’t seem like much, but you taste it, and it’s plentiful." Isn't that what a weeknight steak sandwich should be about?
